info.game_comments: First show consolation prizes appeared in lectern score displays at the conclusion of the game.

(1, 1).clue: The problem in this 1902 story is for Sherlock to find the beast (or man) that's been killing folks on the Devonshire moors

(2, 1).clue: The Huntington Library has some jewels--a manuscript of "The Canterbury Tales" (c. 1410) & one of his Bibles (c. 1455)

(3, 1).clue: A flat piece of absorbent material on which you wipe your feet before entering a house

(4, 1).clue: This Spielberg film featured a longer ending in which Richard Dreyfuss explores the mother ship
(4, 1).correct response: Close Encounters of the Third Kind

(6, 1).clue: The outward projection of a hat

(1, 2).clue: In this story Bilbo & the dwarves have to get a pile of treasure out from under a dragon

(2, 2).clue: Hebrew university has his archives--digitized, too, so you can see his notes on relativity in his hand

(3, 2).clue: This basic type of sheet has elastic edges tailored to grip a mattress; can somebodv help me fold it?

(4, 2).clue: A blood-craving Audrey II "branches" out & takes over NYC in Frank Oz' ending that never was to this film

(6, 2).clue: Filled with gloom, like a certain reaper

(1, 3).clue: Sydney Carton solves the problem of saving Charles Darnay's neck (literally) in this work

(2, 3).clue: Apollo astronauts collected 841 pounds of these (most are stored at Johnson space center)

(3, 3).clue: From the Greek for heavy fabric, it's the type of thick wall covering seen here

(4, 3).clue: An alternate ending for this movie has Will Smith alive & a reunion of vampire lovers

(1, 4).clue: In this 1980 Ludlum thriller, an amnesiac is faced with the problem of reconstructing his past while dodging killers

(2, 4).clue: A 17-ton piece of its hull was recovered from its wreckage site, 450 miles off the coast of Newfoundland

(3, 4).clue: Named for an 18th century London draper, it's a small, lacy, ornamental cloth

(4, 4).clue: Dante got shot while minding the convenience store in the original end of this Kevin Smith comedy

(6, 4).clue: A sudden, capricious desire or act

(1, 5).clue: Porfiry's problem in this story is to get Raskolnikov to confess

(2, 5).clue: The oldest artifact in D.C.'s Newseum is a 3,200-year-old Sumerian brick that spread the news using this writing system

(3, 5).clue: It's not something false, it's a decorative covering for a pillow

(4, 5).clue: The original script for this Jamie Foxx film set in Saudi Arabia had his FBI team getting blown up

(1, 1).clue: 12 hens each lay a half dozen eggs, but 2 get broken; then a hen lays one more, leaving this many unbroken eggs

(3, 1).clue: The 18th c. fanfare heard here is the theme for this PBS show that's brought class & drama to American TV

(4, 1).clue: Until 1792 Kentucky was a part of this state

(5, 1).clue: From the Dutch for "to cross", it's a pleasure trip taken aboard ship

(6, 1).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from the California Highway Patrol Academy in Sacramento, CA.)  Though they've ridden Harleys & Kawasakis, the CHP has been riding motorcycles made by this Munich-based company since the 1990s

(1, 2).clue: If a lepidopterist spots 4 butterflies, each with 3 black spots & 5 yellow spots, he spots this many spots

(3, 2).clue: The evening newscast by Chet Huntley & this partner used Beethoven's 9th for its theme

(4, 2).clue: Reflecting the state nickname, the International Museum for this genre of music is in Owensboro

(6, 2).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from the California Highway Patrol Academy in Sacramento, CA.)  The Breathalyzer will test to see if I'm over this blood alcohol content; its enactment as the limit in all 50 states has saved many lives

(1, 3).clue: The "Jeopardy!" writers drank 72 beers after work yesterday: 20 in the 1st round, 26 in the 2nd & this many at last call

(3, 3).clue: Appropriately, the series titled this director "Presents" used a funeral march by Gounod as its theme

(4, 3).clue: This racetrack is home to the Kentucky Derby

(1, 4).clue: A widget costs 64 cents & you pay with a dollar; you get 4 coins in change, these
(1, 4).correct response: a penny, a quarter & two nickels

(3, 4).clue: In 1829, though he didn't know it, he composed the theme music for "The Lone Ranger"

(4, 4).clue: The first of these restaurants was opened by Colonel Harland Sanders in Corbin, Kentucky

(5, 4).clue: A medical charlatan, it's from a longer Dutch word meaning one who applies a phony cure-all ointment

(1, 5).clue: A scout troop hikes 3 miles due north, 4 miles due east & straight back this far to their starting point

(3, 5).clue: The overture to Reznicek's "Donna Diana" introduced this TV mountie "of the Yukon"

(4, 5).clue: Not Calhoun but this John C. from Kentucky was U.S. VP from 1857 to 1861 & then Sec. of War for the Confederacy

(5, 5).clue: This term for a leave of absence granted to a member of the military is from a Dutch word for "permission"

(6, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew reports from the California Highway Patrol Academy in Sacramento, CA.)  Named for a slain nine-year-old girl, these alerts issued by the CHP are an attempt to galvanize a community into looking for a missing child

(0, 0).clue: In 1875 she wrote, "Jesus of Nazareth was the most scientific man that ever trod the globe"
